DISTRIBUTION : NA .

NEW
RECORDS
: BM 52 , BM 53 , BM 54 .

REMARKS : These are the first records from the Adriatic Sea. However, the identification is uncertain and in need of verification. According to
Chambers & Muir ( 1997 )
H. glabra
occurs in the North East Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea, while
Barnich & Fiege ( 2003 )
consider the presence of this species in the Mediterranean as uncertain.
Harmothoe glabra
has been often confused or synonymized with
H. longisetis (
Grube, 1863
)
, but according to
Barnich & Fiege ( 2000 )
the two species should be considered as distinct. Due to the confusion between the two taxa, all literature records of these species in the Mediterranean Sea and North-Eastern Atlantic are doubtful and need to be confirmed (
Barnich & Fiege 2000
, 2003 ).
DISTRIBUTION : NA , SA.
DISTRIBUTION : NA , CA, SA.

REMARKS : Due to the confusion of
H. impar
with other similar taxa (
H. aspera (Hansen, 1879 )
,
H. bellani
Barnich & Fiege 2000
,
H. extenuata (
Grube 1840
)
,
H. fragilis Moore, 1910
,
H. gilchristi Day, 1960
,
H. goreensis Augener, 1918
and
H. pagenstecheri Michaelsen, 1896
), the previous records of these species in the Mediterranean and North East Atlantic are doubtful and need to be confirmed (
Barnich & Fiege 2003
). The previous records of
H. reticulata (Claparède, 1870 )
in the Adriatic should be referred to
H. impar
.
DISTRIBUTION : NA , SA.

REMARKS :
Tebble & Chambers ( 1982 )
considered
Evarne johnstoni McIntosh, 1876
indeterminable, as the type specimen lacks elytra and the description is insufficient to characterize the taxon.
